docs.lead_paragraph: TO the women he dated, Jeff Gundersen was all things wonderful. He was handsome, athletic and successful, a Wall Street headhunter who lived in a garden apartment on Gramercy Park. At 50, Mr. Gundersen, a divorced father of three, wanted to remarry, but there was a catch: he didn't want more children. ''I was dating women in their 30's, and for many it was a deal breaker,'' Mr. Gundersen said. ''I had already done the diapers, the weekend soccer games and the late nights with the kids' homework. I had been there and was happy to have my own life back.''

headline.main: A Promise to Love, Honor and Bear No Children

docs.abstract: Article on wealthy and powerful older men who are marrying 'trophy' wives, but only with stipulation, often in prenuptial contracts, that they will not have children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The confirma-tion of President Bush's nominee as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Mark B. McClellan, encountered a snag because of a dispute about health care for poor pregnant women and their fetuses. A spokeswoman for Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, said he was blocking the nomination to protest a new regulation that lets states classify fetuses as ''unborn children'' eligible for health programs for uninsured low-income people. Advocates of abortion rights welcome expanding prenatal care, but object to giving fetuses separate legal status.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Dispute On Fetuses Stalls Nomination

docs.lead_paragraph: It may seem hard to believe that a disorder first identified nearly 70 years ago that affects as many as 10 percent of women would still be unrecognized by many doctors and in most of those who have it. But that is the case with a condition called polycystic ovary syndrome, or PCOS, a bodywide metabolic disorder characterized by abnormal hormone levels that can result in distressing and sometimes life-threatening problems, including infertility, obesity, acne, excessive facial and body hair, diabetes, heart disease and uterine cancer.

headline.main: Women Can Fight an Almost Secret Syndrome

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on polycystic ovary syndrome, bodywide metabolic disorder in women characterized by abnormal hormone levels; syndrome can result in distressing and sometimes life-threatening problems; describes syndrome, its diagnosis and treatment and related emotional problems; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past decade, fertility experts have made major advances in reproductive technology. They have learned how to inject a single microscopic sperm into an egg to ensure fertilization; they can retrieve an egg from one woman, fertilize it and implant it into another's uterus; and they have succeeded in freezing a young woman's eggs so she could have access to them later in life when she is ready to reproduce. But increasingly these experts are finding that they must pay attention to the most fundamental and low-tech of issues, the emotional health of their infertility patients.

headline.main: Fertility Clinics Begin to Address Mental Health

docs.abstract: Article on new focus by many infertility centers in US on emotional health of their patients; about half of 370 centers approved by Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology have hired psychologists and started support groups and stress-reduction workshops in past two years; photo; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Common Thread: Mothers, Daughters and the Power of Empathy,'' by Dr. Martha Manning, William Morrow/HarperCollins, $39.50. Why, the psychologist-author of this thoughtful book asks, do we spend hours thinking about our mothers and daughters? Her answer: ''Because it's the longest-running show in town and we've had front-row seats for our entire lives. Some of us got our tickets for free, and others paid dearly for them.''
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book The Common Thread: Mothers, Daughters and the Power of Empathy by Dr Martha Manning; photo (M)
